tips: Job's intense lament after seven days of silence

He questions the purpose of suffering and why he was born into misery

tips: The raw honesty in 'I wish I had died at birth' (v. 10) - this is a powerful expression of despair
The question 'Why have you made me to be born?' (v. 11) shows deep anguish
The contrast between his suffering and the divine order (v. 12)

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Job trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage?
tips: Job's lament shows that suffering can be a cry to God, not a sin

The author emphasizes that even in the deepest despair, the believer can still have a relationship with God

The question 'Why have you made me to be born?' (v. 11) is a common question in the suffering experience

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (Eliphaz) does WHAT (argues that Job must have sinned) to those who suffer (Job), WHERE (in the context of Job's suffering), and WHY (because he believes suffering is punishment for sin)
tips: Include Eliphaz's claim that the innocent do not perish (v. 8-9)

The key event: Eliphaz states that Job's suffering is because he has sinned secretly (v. 11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Eliphaz's claim about the righteous (v. 11), the accusation of sowing trouble (v. 11), or the phrase 'the innocent do not perish' (v. 9)?
tips: The phrase 'the righteous man is not destroyed' (v. 11) is a strong theological assertion that contrasts with Job's suffering
The accusation 'you have sown trouble' (v. 11) is subtle but direct, showing Eliphaz's confidence in his own understanding
The phrase 'the innocent do not perish' (v. 9) is a common theme but misapplied here

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Eliphaz trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage?
tips: Eliphaz is addressing the common belief that suffering indicates sin, but he is not considering the possibility of God's sovereign purposes
This message was intended to comfort those who suffer by giving them a reason for their pain, but it leads to the wrong conclusion
Note that Eliphaz's theology is a form of retribution theology that assumes suffering is always punishment for sin

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The claim that the innocent do not perish, the use of 'night vision', and the theological error of assuming all suffering is punishment for sin?
tips: In Hebrew, the term for 'vision' (he'ar) can mean a dream or a spiritual encounter, but in this context, it's a night vision that Eliphaz claims to have had
The idea of 'sowing trouble' (v. 11) implies that Job's suffering is a direct result of his own sin, which is a common belief in the ancient world but not the full picture
The concept of retribution theology (suffering as punishment for sin) is a common theme in the ancient Near East, but it's not the only explanation for suffering

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: When you face suffering, don't assume it's because you've sinned. Instead, trust God's purpose. What situation requires you to trust God's provision this week?
tips: This week, when you face suffering, ask: 'Is this punishment for my sin, or is it part of God's plan?'
Practice the prayer of Job 4:11: 'I have seen a vision in the night' - meaning, seek God's perspective in your suffering
Consider an area where you're holding back from full obedience and ask God to reveal His purpose

tips: Job is the one suffering and responding to his friends' comfort
The key event is his accusation that his friends are like a wadi that dries up (v.6)
He wishes for God to crush him (v.4)

questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the weight of anguish (v.1-2), the wadi metaphor (v.6), or the plea for honesty (v.8).
tips: The comparison of his friends to a wadi that dries up when most needed is powerful because it shows their uselessness in his time of need
The phrase 'I have spoken' (v.8) is repeated to show his desperation for truth
The wish for God to crush him (v.4) is a raw expression of the unbearable weight of suffering

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Job trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage?
tips: Job is expressing that the suffering is too heavy and his friends have failed him, but he longs for the true friend who will not abandon him
This foreshadows Christ who is the true friend who remains even in our darkest hours
The key is that God is the only one who will not fail us

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The metaphor of the wadi, the desire for death, and the accusation against friends.
tips: The wadi (a dry river) in the desert context represents a temporary, unreliable source of water; Job is saying his friends are like that when he needs them most
The phrase 'crush me' (v.4) is an extreme expression of suffering but shows Job's depth of pain
The accusation that friends are 'worthless' (v.6) is harsh but reflects the reality of how comfort can become torment when it's not genuine

This passage encourages those who suffer to seek divine pardon when they feel guilty (v.5)

Job's question about pardon (v.5) reflects his belief that he might have sinned, but he is still seeking God's mercy

Pay attention to the phrase 'how can a man be right with God' in verse 10 - this is the core question
Notice the contrast between God's power (v.10-12) and human helplessness (v.13-20)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Job) does WHAT (describes God's power and his helplessness), WHERE (in the heavens, as described in Job 9), and WHY (to question how he can be right with God).
tips: Include Job's description of God's power in creation (v.10: 'I have made the sun, I have set it in its place')
Note Job's plea for an arbiter (v.18-20: 'I wish that there were an arbiter between me and God')
Describe the emotional state of Job as he feels overwhelmed by God's power

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the question 'how can a man be right with God' (v.10), Job's description of God's power (v.10-12), or his plea for an arbiter (v.18-20).
tips: The phrase 'how can a man be right with God' (v.10) is a profound question that every sufferer can relate to
Job's description of God's power (v.10: 'I have made the sun, I have set it in its place') shows God's control beyond human understanding
The plea for an arbiter (v.18-20) reflects Job's deep need for fairness and understanding in a situation of divine mystery

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Job trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage?
tips: Job is expressing the helplessness of the human condition in the face of God's overwhelming power
He is questioning the possibility of being righteous before God, which leads to the need for a mediator
This passage foreshadows the need for Christ as the ultimate mediator between God and humanity

Job's description of God's power (v.10-12) is poetic and not meant to be a historical account but to show God's sovereignty
The term 'arbiter' (v.18-20) refers to a mediator in ancient Near Eastern context, which Job is using to express his need for fairness

questions.title: Summary

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Job's opening question (v.1), the clay metaphor (v.8), or the wish for death at birth (v.17).
tips: The direct question 'Why do you contend against me?' shows Job's desperation for understanding
The clay metaphor (v.8) emphasizes God's careful creation, which contrasts with current suffering
The wish 'I wish that I had never been born' (v.17) is a profound expression of suffering that resonates with human experience

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Job trying to communicate to those who suffer through his plea in this chapter?
tips: Job's experience of God's hiddenness and the pain of suffering
The need for believers to express their pain to God without fear
The connection to Christ's cry on the cross: 'My God, why have you forsaken me?'

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The Hebrew term for 'contend', the image of God 'hunting', and the wish for death at birth.
tips: The Hebrew word 'māšāl' (to contend) means God's opposition, not a battle
The phrase 'God hunts me like a lion' (v.8) is a metaphor for relentless suffering
The statement 'I wish I had not been born' (v.17) is an extreme expression of suffering that is not meant to be taken literally but as a cry for help

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Job's cry for death at birth shows the depth of his suffering. What situation requires you to express your pain to God without fear this week?
tips: Consider an area where you are holding back from expressing your pain to God
Think about how Job's wish for death at birth reflects a deep need for relief from suffering
Practically, try to write down your pain and share it with God in prayer this week

tips: Thank God for forming you with care (v.8)

questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Zophar) is speaking to, WHAT (his accusations against Job), WHERE (in the context of Job's suffering), and WHY (to challenge Job's claim of righteousness and call for repentance).
tips: Zophar accuses Job of being a liar and hiding sin (v. 14)

Zophar demands Job repent and turn to God for security (v. 16-17)

questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Zophar's description of God's wisdom (v. 7-8), his demand for repentance (v. 16-17), or the contrast between human understanding and divine wisdom (v. 9-10).
tips: 'God's wisdom is unsearchable, higher than heaven, deeper than Sheol' (v. 7-8) shows the vast gulf between human and divine
Zophar's call for Job to 'put away iniquity and turn to God' (v. 16) is a practical challenge to Job's complacency
The phrase 'God exacts less than Job's guilt deserves' (v. 19) highlights the severity of Job's sin according to Zophar

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Zophar trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage?
tips: Zophar's message is that suffering is a result of hidden sin and that true security comes through repentance and humility
This passage reminds those in suffering that God's wisdom is beyond human comprehension, so we must not claim to know God's judgments
The author (unknown) intended to show that even the wisest of men (Zophar) cannot understand God's ways, so we should seek God's wisdom in humility

The phrase 'iniquity' (v. 14) is a term that can be interpreted broadly, including both moral and spiritual failure

Pray for humility to admit our hidden sins
Ask God to help us trust His justice even when we don't understand

Pay attention to the imagery of the moon and stars being 'not bright' and 'not pure' (v.5)
The phrase 'maggot and worm' (v.6) is a stark image of human decay and insignificance

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Bildad) is speaking, WHAT (his argument about human sinfulness and God's justice), WHERE (in the context of Job's suffering), and WHY (to address Job's suffering).
tips: Include the contrast between God's majesty and human insignificance
Note that Bildad is responding to Job's suffering and the question of divine justice
Bildad's argument is that humans are too sinful to be righteous before God

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the contrast of God's power (v.1-3), the image of human decay (v.5-6), or the rhetorical questions (v.2-3).
tips: The rhetorical questions in v.2-3: 'How can man be right before God? How can one born of woman be pure?' are powerful because they highlight the human condition without offering hope
The image of the moon and stars being 'not bright' and 'not pure' (v.5) is a striking contrast to the human condition
The phrase 'maggot and worm' (v.6) is a visceral image of human corruption and insignificance

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Bildad trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage?
tips: Bildad's intention was to affirm God's absolute sovereignty and human sinfulness, but this misses the point of Job's suffering
This speech is an example of a 'righteous' person who fails to grasp the gospel solution to suffering
The author's purpose is to show that Bildad's view is incomplete and that the true answer to suffering is found in Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The statement about God's power, the comparison of humans to maggot and worm, or the implications for suffering?
tips: The phrase 'maggot and worm' (v.6) is a metaphor for human decay and insignificance, but in ancient Near Eastern context, maggot and worm were associated with death and decay
The rhetorical questions in v.2-3 assume that humans are inherently sinful, but they don't address the possibility of divine intervention in suffering
The contrast between God's light (v.1) and human darkness (v.6) might be difficult to reconcile with the hope of redemption

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Bildad's focus on human sinfulness and God's power misses the point of suffering. What specific area of your life requires you to trust God's provision instead of human righteousness?
tips: Consider an area where you feel inadequate and need God's grace rather than your own efforts
How can you practice humility in the face of God's majesty, without falling into despair?
This week, ask God to help you see that your suffering is not a sign of sin, but an opportunity to trust Him

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His sovereignty and ask for help to see the gospel answer to suffering.
tips: Thank God that He is the ultimate ruler and that His justice is beyond human understanding
Pray for the grace to accept that our suffering is not a sign of sin but a call to trust Christ
Ask God to help you see that the true righteousness comes through Christ, not human effort

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 26:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the poetic descriptions of God's power in verses 3, 7, and 10.
tips: Notice the phrase 'Sheol is naked before Him' (v.3) which emphasizes God's sovereignty over the dead
Pay attention to the imagery of God 'stretches out the north over the void' (v.7) and 'hangs the earth on nothing' (v.7)
The repetition of God's power (v.7-10) shows the vastness of creation

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Job) is speaking, WHAT (God's power) is described, WHERE (in the heavens) and WHEN (in Job's response to his friends), and WHY (to address the suffering of the powerless).
tips: Job is the speaker (v.1)
God's power is described: stretching the north, hanging the earth, binding waters, setting the horizon (v.7-10)
This happens after Job's friends have spoken (v.1-5) and is a response to their questions about suffering

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of Sheol (v.3), the image of God 'stretches out the north' (v.7), or the 'whisper' of God (v.14)?
tips: The phrase 'Sheol is naked before Him' (v.3) shows God's complete authority over death and the dead
The imagery of God 'stretches out the north over the void' (v.7) demonstrates His control over the universe
The 'whisper' of God (v.14) highlights the mystery and awe of God's power beyond human understanding

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Job trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage?
tips: Job is reminding the suffering that God's power is beyond human comprehension and the source of all creation
This passage addresses the helplessness of the powerless (as Job sarcastically questions his friends' help)
The main point: God's majestic power is the ultimate answer to suffering and the source of hope

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'Sheol', the poetic description of God's power, or the 'whisper' of God?
tips: Sheol (v.3) is the Hebrew word for the underworld or grave, not the Christian concept of hell
The phrase 'hangs the earth on nothing' (v.7) is a poetic expression for God holding the earth without physical support
The 'whisper' (v.14) refers to the divine mystery that is beyond human understanding, which is a theme of the passage

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of God's power beyond human understanding. What situation requires you to trust God's power this week?
tips: When facing a problem that seems unsolvable (like a health crisis), trust that God's power is greater than your situation
Practice humility by acknowledging that you cannot understand God's ways
Pray for God's strength to trust His power in your current challenges

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His majestic power and ask for comfort in the midst of suffering.
tips: Thank God for His power that is beyond human understanding
Ask for courage to trust God's power in your suffering
Pray that the 'whisper' of God (v.14) brings clarity and hope

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 27:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'I will not' and the phrase 'my conscience does not reproach me'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I will not' (Job 27:1, 3, 4, 5)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of firmness and conviction in verses 1-4
The phrase 'my conscience does not reproach me' (v.5) is a key declaration of innocence

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Job) is speaking, WHAT he vows (he will not speak falsehood or concede the friends are right), WHERE this oath is made (in the context of his suffering), and WHY he makes it (to defend his integrity and righteousness).
tips: Include Job's response to his friends' accusations
Note that he is holding fast to his righteousness (v.10)
The oath is made to protect his innocence from false accusations

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider Job's oath (v.1-4), the description of the wicked (v.10-11), or his clear conscience (v.5).
tips: Job's oath of integrity (v.1-4) is powerful because he stands firm despite pressure
The contrast between the wicked's fate (children face the sword) and Job's clear conscience (v.5) is striking
The phrase 'my conscience does not reproach me' (v.5) shows deep inner peace

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Job trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage?
tips: Job is addressing the suffering by showing that true integrity and righteousness are not shaken by false accusations
This passage provides hope that the righteous will be vindicated and the wicked will face consequences
The theological significance: the righteous have a clear conscience and will not be destroyed like the wicked

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The description of the wicked's fate, the meaning of 'conscience', and Job's refusal to speak falsehood in the context of his friends' accusations.
tips: The phrase 'the children of the wicked' (v.11) refers to children destroyed by the wicked's actions, not literal children
In Hebrew, 'conscience' (v.5) means inner witness to God, not modern psychological concepts
Job's refusal to speak falsehood (v.1) is a defense against his friends' accusations of sin

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Job's vow of integrity stands firm even when accused. What situation requires you to stand firm in your truth this week?
tips: Consider a situation where you are being accused of something you didn't do
How can you practice Job's integrity by refusing to confess falsehoods?
Ask God for strength to hold fast to your righteousness when pressured

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the strength to stand firm in truth when accused. Ask for courage to hold fast to your integrity in difficult circumstances.
tips: Thank God for Job's example of maintaining innocence
Pray for courage to speak truth when it's costly
Ask God to help you hold fast to your righteousness when under pressure

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 28:1-28 aloud, paying attention to the poetic contrast between human mining efforts and the hidden nature of wisdom.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the fear of the Lord' as the definition of wisdom (v. 28)
Pay attention to the contrast in verses 1-11: human efforts to find wisdom versus its inaccessibility
Listen for the majestic tone that emphasizes God's uniqueness in wisdom

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is the subject (the voice of wisdom), WHAT wisdom is being discussed, WHERE it is found (or not), and WHY this matters to those who suffer.
tips: Include the claim that wisdom is hidden from all living and cannot be mined or bought
Note the contrast between human ingenuity (mining) and divine wisdom
Highlight the audience: those who suffer (Job's context)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of human mining (vv. 1-11), the claim that wisdom is hidden (vv. 12-13), or the divine revelation (vv. 23-28)?
tips: The phrase 'the fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom' (v. 28) is a concise and profound statement that resonates because it's practical and foundational
The contrast in verses 12-13: 'It is hidden from all who live, and no living thing can find it' emphasizes the inaccessibility of wisdom to humans
The divine perspective in verse 25: 'Only God knows the way of wisdom' shows the uniqueness of God's knowledge

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage?
tips: The author is addressing the suffering (like Job) by saying that true wisdom comes from God, not from human efforts
This passage affirms that God is the ultimate source of wisdom and that the fear of the Lord is the foundation of wisdom
Theological significance: This contrasts with the false wisdom of the world and points to God's sovereignty

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'the fear of the Lord', the concept of wisdom being hidden, or the contrast between human and divine wisdom?
tips: 'The fear of the Lord' (Hebrew: yir'ah) means reverence and awe for God, not fear in the emotional sense
Wisdom is hidden from all living (v. 13) does not mean it is absent; it means humans cannot find it on their own
The contrast: human efforts (mining) are limited, but God knows the way of wisdom (v. 25) - this emphasizes God's uniqueness

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the idea that the fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom in your life this week?
tips: When you face a situation where you feel lost or confused, recall that true wisdom comes from God
Practice a daily act of reverence for God (e.g., a moment of quiet reflection) as a step toward wisdom
Ask God to help you trust His wisdom in your specific circumstances

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of wisdom being hidden and only known through God.
tips: Thank God for revealing that true wisdom comes from Him, not from human efforts
Ask for courage to trust God in times of suffering, knowing His wisdom is greater than human understanding
Pray for the gift of reverence for God (fear of the Lord) to guide your decisions

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 29:1-29 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between Job's past blessings and his current suffering.
tips: Notice the repetition of God's watchful care: 'God watched over him' (v.10) and 'by God's light' (v.10)
Pay attention to the emotional tone: Job's memory is joyful but also hints at the pain of loss (v.19)
The phrase 'his glory fresh' (v.18) is a key emotional phrase that evokes hope

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Job) does WHAT (helps the poor, is respected), WHERE (in his former life), and WHY (to reflect God's provision and care).
tips: Include: Job's role as a helper for the poor (v.14) and his respected position (v.10)
Note the contrast: Job's past blessing vs. current suffering (as Job is in the middle of suffering)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Job's rescue of the poor (v.14), being eyes to the blind (v.15), or expecting to die in his nest with fresh glory (v.18).
tips: The phrase 'widow's heart to sing' (v.14) shows the joy in helping the vulnerable
Being 'eyes to the blind' (v.15) is a powerful metaphor for seeing and acting for others
Expecting to die in his nest with fresh glory (v.18) reflects a deep trust in God's provision

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Job trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage?
tips: Job is reminding the suffering (who he is in the present) that God had blessed him in the past and that his current suffering is temporary
The main point is that God's care and provision in the past (and even now) is a foundation for hope

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The memory of past blessing, the meaning of 'fresh glory', and the cultural context of the time.
tips: Job's memory of past blessing is a contrast to his current suffering, but it's not a denial of his present pain
The word 'fresh' here likely means 'new and unspoiled' (not worn out by time or hardship)
In ancient Near East, community leaders often had a role in resolving disputes and helping the poor, which is what Job describes

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Job's description of helping the poor and the widow's heart singing—how can you apply this to your life this week?
tips: This week, identify one person in your community who is struggling and take a concrete step to help them, just as Job did
Practice being 'eyes to the blind' by asking someone who is struggling what they need and acting on it

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the past blessings that are a foundation for hope, and ask for the strength to help others as Job did.
tips: Thank God for the blessings that were once in your life, and that He still cares for you
Pray for the courage to help others in need, as Job did
Ask God to help you remember the past blessings that are a foundation for hope

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 30:1-27 aloud, focusing on the emotional tone of the suffering described.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'he has become' (v.27) to emphasize the depth of his condition
Pay attention to the phrase 'men whose fathers he wouldn't have set with his dogs' (v.1) - a stark contrast to Job's former status
Notice the progression from mockery (v.1-2) to physical torment (v.3-4) to divine silence (v.5-6) and ultimate desolation (v.27)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (Job), WHAT (his current suffering), WHERE (in the context of his life), and WHY (as a result of God's discipline) in your own words.
tips: Include the mockery by those who were once lower in status (v.1-2)
Note the physical torment and loss of prosperity (v.3-4)
Describe the divine silence and the feeling of being abandoned (v.5-6)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the mockery by his inferiors (v.1), the physical torment (v.3-4), or the image of being a brother to jackals (v.27)?
tips: The phrase 'men whose fathers he wouldn't have set with his dogs' (v.1) shows the complete reversal of status
The image of 'he has become a brother to jackals' (v.27) is a powerful metaphor for utter desolation and shame
The physical description of 'pain gnaws his bones' (v.3) emphasizes the relentless nature of suffering

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author trying to communicate to those who suffer through Job's present misery?
tips: The passage shows that suffering can lead to a complete reversal of status and identity, but the author intends to remind the sufferer that God's silence does not mean abandonment
This passage foreshadows Christ's suffering: just as Job was mocked and abandoned, Christ was despised by those He came to save
The author's purpose is to encourage the sufferer to trust God even when there is no visible response

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The cultural context of status, the meaning of 'brother to jackals', and the divine silence?
tips: The phrase 'men whose fathers he wouldn't have set with his dogs' (v.1) reflects a cultural practice where one's status was determined by family. Job would not have associated these men with his dogs
The metaphor 'brother to jackals' (v.27) is a strong image of being reduced to a level of animal, which was a common expression of utter desolation in ancient Near Eastern cultures
Divine silence (v.5-6) is not a rejection of God but a test of faith; the author implies that God is still present but not speaking in the suffering

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Job's experience of divine silence to a current situation where you feel God is silent?
tips: When you feel God's silence, remember Job's cry and pray for the strength to trust in His ultimate provision
Practice the discipline of speaking to God even when there is no answer (as Job did)
Identify one area where you are being mocked or attacked by others and pray for protection and peace

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His faithfulness in the midst of suffering. Ask for strength to endure when others mock and attack you.
tips: Thank God that He does not abandon His children in suffering
Pray for courage to speak to God when you feel silent
Ask God to help you see Christ in the midst of your suffering

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 31:1-31 aloud, focusing on the list of oaths (vv. 1-28) and the final declaration (v.31).
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I have not...' (vv. 5-28)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Job) is making an oath, WHAT (a comprehensive list of ethical righteousness), WHERE (in his heart), and WHY (to defend himself against false accusations).
tips: Include the 15+ specific ethical standards he has not violated
Note that he is speaking to his friends who have accused him
Highlight the contrast between his innocence and the friends' claims

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Job's vow to not gaze at a virgin (v.1), his list of ethical failures avoided (v.5-28), or his final cry for divine justice (v.31).
tips: The vow to not gaze at a virgin shows deep commitment to purity and respect for women
The list of avoided sins (e.g., not being deceitful) demonstrates a holistic ethic
The final declaration 'Let the Almighty answer me!' is a powerful cry for God's intervention

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Job trying to communicate to those suffering (like himself) about the nature of righteousness and God's justice?
tips: Job shows that true righteousness requires lifelong ethical commitment
He challenges the idea that suffering is always punishment for sin
The passage implies only God's justice can ultimately vindicate the innocent

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The list of ethical standards, the cultural context of the oaths, or the concept of divine justice in suffering?
tips: 'I have not walked in falsehood' (v.5) refers to both moral and financial dishonesty in ancient context
The list of specific sins (e.g., 'lured by another's wife') is culturally specific and may not be directly applicable today
'The Almighty' (v.31) implies a God who is both powerful and just, which can be hard to reconcile with human suffering

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Job's comprehensive oath shows that true righteousness requires daily ethical choices. What specific ethical area (e.g., honesty in business, respect for others) can you commit to this week?
tips: Identify one area where you have been tempted to compromise (e.g., financial integrity)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His justice and righteousness. Ask for the strength to live righteously in the midst of trials, and for the courage to stand before Him with a clear conscience.
tips: Thank God for the example of Job's integrity
Pray for the grace to avoid the sins he lists (e.g., deceit)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 32:1-32 aloud, focusing on Elihu's introduction and his argument against the friends.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I have waited' (v.15) shows his patience and then anger
Pay attention to the repeated phrase 'the Spirit of God' (v.15,26)
The emotional tone shifts from quiet to urgent as he speaks

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Elihu, Job, the friends) does WHAT (speaks against the friends' accusations), WHERE (at Job's house), and WHY (because he felt the friends were unjust and Job was self-justifying).
tips: Elihu is young and had been silent out of respect
The friends had been speaking for 7 days without addressing Job's suffering
Elihu argues that the Spirit of God, not age, gives wisdom

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Elihu's statement about waiting (v.15), his claim about the Spirit (v.15), or his youth (v.26).
tips: Elihu's declaration that 'the Spirit of God' gives understanding (v.15) is revolutionary because it points to divine wisdom beyond human experience
His youth (v.26) contrasts with the older friends and shows that wisdom comes from God, not age
The phrase 'I have waited' (v.15) reveals his patience and then his frustration

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage?
tips: The passage addresses the suffering of Job and his friends' failure to understand
It emphasizes that true wisdom comes from the Spirit of God, not from the accumulation of years or human reasoning
This is especially relevant for those who feel they have been wronged by others or by God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? Why does Elihu speak so early? What does 'the Spirit of God' mean in this context? How does his youth relate to wisdom?
tips: Elihu had been silent for a long time because of respect for the elders, but now he speaks because he feels the friends were wrong and Job was self-justifying
In the Old Testament, the Spirit of God is often associated with revelation (e.g., in the Pentateuch), but here it points to the divine source of wisdom
The phrase 'younger' (v.26) refers to age and experience, not just physical age

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Elihu's claim that the Spirit of God gives wisdom (not just age) teaches us to seek divine wisdom in our struggles. What situation this week requires you to trust the Spirit's guidance over your own experience or the wisdom of others?
tips: Consider a decision where you feel you don't have enough wisdom
Think about how to pray for the Spirit's guidance in that situation
Practice listening for the Spirit's voice in your daily life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the Spirit of God to give wisdom and understanding in your struggles, just as Elihu experienced.
tips: Thank God for the Spirit who gives wisdom beyond age
Ask for courage to speak truth when others are silent
Pray for the Spirit to guide you in a situation where you feel you are suffering

chapters.chapterTitle: Elihu's First Speech: God Speaks in Many Ways

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 33:1-38 aloud, paying attention to Elihu's confident tone and direct address to Job in verses 1-2.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'God speaks' (v.12-15) emphasizing God's active communication
Pay attention to Elihu's challenge to Job's claim of innocence in verses 1-10
The phrase 'the pit' (v.25) symbolizes deep spiritual distress

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Elihu) speaks to WHO (Job), WHAT (God's communication and restoration), WHERE (in the context of Job's suffering), and WHY (to correct Job's claim of innocence).
tips: Include Elihu's challenge to Job's innocence (v.1-10)
Note God's communication through dreams, visions, and pain (v.12-15)
Highlight the restoration from the pit to righteousness (v.25)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's communication in dreams and visions (v.12-15), the mediator for the near-dead (v.23-24), or God's repeated work of restoration (v.25).
tips: The phrase 'God speaks in many ways' (v.12) is the central thesis of the chapter
Elihu's description of the mediator as one who 'interprets' and 'redeems' (v.24) points to Christ
The image of being 'brought from the pit to the light of life' (v.25) is a powerful metaphor for spiritual renewal

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Elihu trying to communicate to those who suffer through this speech?
tips: Elihu addresses the complaint of suffering people: God's silence
He shows God speaks in varied ways (dreams, visions, pain) rather than only through words
The mediator (Christ) is the one who restores people from sin to righteousness

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of the mediator, the phrase 'God speaks in many ways', and the concept of 'the pit'.
tips: In ancient Near Eastern context, a mediator was a human intermediary but Elihu points to Christ
The phrase 'God speaks in many ways' (v.12) means God communicates through various means, not that He is silent
'The pit' (v.25) refers to a state of deep spiritual distress or sin, not a physical location

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Elihu says God restores people from the pit through a mediator. What situation this week requires you to trust God's mediator (Christ) to bring you back to righteousness?
tips: Consider a time when you feel 'near death' (spiritually) and need restoration
Pray for the mediator (Christ) to interpret your situation and bring you back to God
This week, seek God's voice in dreams, visions, or pain to understand His plan

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's communication in the ways He speaks (dreams, visions, pain) and for the mediator to restore you from the pit.
tips: Thank God for speaking to you in ways that may be unexpected
Ask for the courage to trust the mediator (Christ) when you feel lost
Pray for God to bring you from the pit to the light of life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 34:1-37 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'God' and the phrase 'He is not partial' in verse 11.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'God' (8 times) and the phrase 'He is not partial' (v.11) which is central
Pay attention to the emotional tone: Elihu is confident and firm, addressing Job's complaint with a sense of divine authority
The phrase 'God does not do wickedness' (v.10) is a key claim that appears repeatedly

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Elihu) is speaking, WHAT (defending God's justice against Job's complaint), WHERE (in the context of Job's suffering), and WHY (to correct Job's misunderstanding about God's righteousness).
tips: Include: Elihu's role as a young relative who speaks after Job's friends (Job 32-33)
Note that Job has complained that righteousness profits nothing (Job 34:2) and Elihu responds that God cannot do wickedness
Focus on the contrast: Job's view vs. Elihu's view of God's justice

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Elihu's claim that God is not partial (v.11), the statement that God repays according to deeds (v.12), or the assertion that no one can condemn the righteous (v.22).
tips: The phrase 'God does not do wickedness' (v.10) is a strong declaration that resonates with the theme of God's inherent justice
The line 'He watches all human ways' (v.19) shows God's all-seeing nature, which addresses the suffering of the poor and wicked
The statement that God shatters the mighty without investigation (v.22) is a powerful reminder of God's impartial judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Elihu trying to communicate to those who suffer (like Job) about God's justice?
tips: Elihu's purpose is to show that God's justice is perfect and impartial, and that Job's complaint about righteousness being unprofitable is wrong because God rewards according to deeds
This points to the reality that God is the righteous judge who will ultimately be just without partiality, and that suffering is part of a larger divine purpose

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The claim that God is not partial? The concept of God repaying according to deeds? The idea that God shatters the mighty without investigation?
tips: The phrase 'God does not do wickedness' (v.10) might be misunderstood as implying God is incapable of evil, but in context it means God's actions are always just and righteous
The term 'repays according to deeds' (v.12) could be seen as retribution, but Elihu emphasizes God's justice as a response to human actions, not arbitrary punishment
The statement that 'no darkness can hide the wicked' (v.19) is a strong claim about God's omniscience and the inevitability of judgment

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Elihu emphasizes that God is not partial and judges all equally. What can you do this week to live with the assurance that God's justice is impartial?
tips: Consider an area where you might be favoring the powerful or ignoring the poor
Practice humility by asking: 'How does my life reflect God's impartiality?'
Pray for the courage to speak out against injustice in your community

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's justice and impartiality in your life and the world.
tips: Thank God that He is the righteous judge who does not favor the powerful
Ask for the strength to stand for justice when it is hard
Pray for a heart that trusts God's justice even when we suffer

Capture the main flow

tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

chapters.chapterTitle: Elihu: God's Greatness and Purpose in Suffering

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 36:1-28 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between God's justice and the godless in heart.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'God is great' (v. 2) and 'He does not despise' (v. 2)
Pay attention to the emotional tone in verses 5-10 where God reveals sin and commands return
Notice the contrast in verses 14-15 between the righteous and the godless

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (God/Elihu) is speaking to, WHAT God does in affliction, WHERE this occurs (in the context of suffering), and WHY (to reveal sin and command return).
tips: Include Elihu's role as the young man who has been listening to Job's complaints
Note that God reveals sin in the afflicted (v. 5) and commands them to return (v. 10)
Highlight the consequence of obedience (prosperity) and disobedience (perishing) in v. 12

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's revelation of sin in affliction (v. 5), the command to return (v. 10), or the consequence of obedience (v. 12).
tips: The phrase 'He reveals their sin' (v. 5) is profound because it shows God's active role in the process of suffering
The contrast in v. 12 between 'prosper' and 'perish' is a powerful reminder of the stakes
The description of the godless in v. 15 highlights the danger of ignoring God's call

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Elihu trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage about God's purpose in affliction?
tips: Elihu addresses Job and others suffering, emphasizing that God's justice is real and that suffering can lead to spiritual renewal
This passage shows that God is not indifferent but actively uses affliction to reveal sin and command return
The theological significance is that suffering has purpose in the life of the believer when it leads to repentance

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of Elihu, the purpose of suffering in revealing sin, or the meaning of 'godless in heart'?
tips: Elihu is a young man who has been listening to Job's complaints (Job 32:1-12) and speaks with wisdom
The purpose of suffering in this context is not punishment but correction and restoration (as in Hebrews 12:7)
The term 'godless' (heathen) in Hebrew (qarim) refers to those without a relationship with God, not the wicked in the sense of evil

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Elihu teaches that suffering reveals sin and commands return. What situation requires you to examine your life for sin and return to God this week?
tips: This week, when you face a trial, take time to reflect on whether there is a sin you need to confess
Ask God to reveal any hidden sin that might be causing you to be bound in affliction
Pray for the courage to return to God when suffering comes

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's purpose in your suffering as described in this passage.
tips: Thank God that He uses suffering to reveal your sin and lead you to repentance
Pray for the strength to return to God when you are bound in affliction
Ask God to help you avoid the anger and helplessness of the godless (v. 15)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 37:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the rhetorical questions and storm imagery.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'God' and the storm imagery: 'He sends the wind' (v. 1), 'the thunder in the sky' (v. 2), 'lightning' (v. 3)
Pay attention to the rhetorical question in verse 6: 'Can you spread out the skies like a molten mirror?'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Elihu) is speaking, WHAT (God's power in the storm), WHERE (in the heavens), and WHY (to address Job's suffering and show God's majesty).
tips: Include Elihu's rhetorical questions about the heavens (v. 6)
Note the contrast between human limitation and God's power (v. 3, 5)
Describe the storm as a visible manifestation of God's presence

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Elihu's rhetorical questions (v. 6), the description of God's majesty (v. 12), or the call to fear God (v. 35)?
tips: The phrase 'God is clothed in awesome majesty' (v. 12) emphasizes God's transcendence
The rhetorical question 'Can you spread out the skies like a molten mirror?' (v. 6) highlights human inability to comprehend God's creation
The closing statement 'Therefore people fear Him' (v. 35) shows the natural response to God's majesty

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Elihu trying to communicate to those who suffer (like Job) about God's nature and response?
tips: Elihu shows that God's power is evident in the storm, which is a theophany (visible manifestation of God)
This passage reassures the suffering that God is both powerful and just, and that their fear is appropriate
The context of Job's suffering (Job 36-37) shows Elihu addressing why God allows suffering

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The storm as God's visible presence? The meaning of 'the storm-god'? The contrast between human and divine?
tips: The term 'theophany' (visible manifestation of God) might be unfamiliar; in this context, the storm is God's active presence
The phrase 'the storm-god' is metaphorical; Elihu means God works through the storm, not that God is a storm
The concept of God's justice and power in the storm differs from the usual understanding of God as a distant ruler

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Elihu's description of God's majesty shows that we are limited. What situation this week requires you to acknowledge God's power and majesty rather than trying to control the storm?
tips: When facing a crisis (like a storm), remember that God is the one in control
In your daily life, try to step back and acknowledge God's power rather than trying to fix everything yourself
Pray for humility in the face of God's majesty

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His power and majesty that we cannot fully comprehend. Ask for the courage to fear Him appropriately.
tips: Thank God for His power and majesty that we cannot fully comprehend
Ask for the courage to fear God appropriately and not to overestimate our own power
Pray for the grace to trust God's provision even in the midst of life's storms

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 38:1-38 aloud, paying attention to the rhetorical questions and the majestic tone of God's speech.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'Who is this that darkens counsel by words without knowledge?' (v. 2)
Pay attention to the contrast between God's sovereignty and Job's limited understanding (e.g., 'Can you bind the Pleiades or loose Orion?' v. 31)
The emotional tone shifts from questioning to a display of God's greatness

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (God) does WHAT (speaks to Job) WHERE (from the whirlwind) and WHY (to demonstrate His sovereignty and the limits of human understanding).
tips: Include God's questions about the foundation of the earth (v. 4-7)
Note the specific creations mentioned: the sea, morning, snow, hail, Pleiades, Orion, lightning, and the hawk (v. 8-38)
Why: To show Job's creaturely limitations and God's absolute sovereignty

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's question about the foundation of the earth (v.4-7), the Pleiades and Orion (v.31), or the hawk's wisdom (v.34)?
tips: The question 'Who is this that darkens counsel by words without knowledge?' (v. 2) directly addresses Job's lack of wisdom
The statement 'Can you bind the Pleiades or loose Orion?' (v. 31) emphasizes the vastness of creation and human insignificance
The question about the hawk's wisdom (v. 34) shows God's control over natural phenomena and the wisdom of His creation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was God trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage?
tips: God is showing that suffering is within His sovereign plan and not arbitrary
The focus is on the limitations of human understanding and the greatness of God's creation
This passage is a response to Job's complaint that God is silent and unresponsive (Job 38:1-38)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The specific references to creation (e.g., Pleiades, Orion), the meaning of 'binding' the stars, and the concept of God's sovereignty over the natural world.
tips: The Pleiades (a star cluster) and Orion (a constellation) were known in ancient times but are not common in modern contexts
'Binding' (Hebrew: kaf) in this context means to restrict or confine the stars to their places
The passage does not explain the purpose of suffering but emphasizes God's sovereignty and the futility of human attempts to understand the universe

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this to your life this week? Consider: When you feel overwhelmed by life's challenges, remember that God's creation is beyond your understanding and He is sovereign.
tips: Acknowledge your limitations in understanding God's plan (Job 38:2)
Practice humility by recognizing that God's wisdom is greater than human wisdom (Job 38:3)
This week, when faced with a difficult situation, pray for God's guidance and trust in His sovereignty

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His sovereignty and the revelation of His greatness in creation.
tips: Thank God for His creation and the revelation of His sovereignty
Ask for humility in the face of God's greatness
Pray for the strength to trust God's plan even when you don't understand

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 39:1-30 aloud, paying attention to God's rhetorical questions and descriptive phrases about animals.
tips: Notice the repetition of God's statements about the animals' characteristics
Pay attention to the contrast between human limitations and God's control (e.g., 'Who sets the wild donkey free?' in v. 13)
Listen for the tone of wisdom and authority in God's speech

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God is speaking to, WHAT he says about the animal kingdom, WHERE this occurs (in the context of Job's suffering), and WHY he does so.
tips: Include the examples of mountain goats giving birth and wild donkeys being set free
Note that God shows Job's lack of knowledge about animal behavior
Describe the contrast between human limitations and God's care for all creation

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the ostrich's wisdom (v. 13), the wild ox (v. 15-16), or the hawk's ability to fly (v. 27-28)?
tips: The ostrich lacks wisdom yet outpaces the horse (v. 13) shows God's design for creatures that are beyond human control
The wild ox is the most powerful animal (v. 15) but still under God's care
The hawk soars without being taught (v. 27-28) illustrates God's provision for creatures that do not need human instruction

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was God trying to communicate to Job (and those who suffer) through this passage about the animal kingdom?
tips: God is showing Job that he cannot govern animals and therefore cannot question God's governance of all creation
This passage exposes Job's limitations and redirects his focus to God's wisdom and care
The theme is that God's provision and control extend to all creation, including the animals, which Job cannot manage

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The rhetorical questions, the specific animals chosen, or the connection to human suffering?
tips: The chapter uses rhetorical questions to highlight Job's ignorance (e.g., 'Who sets the wild donkey free?') without providing answers
The choice of animals (like the ostrich and wild ox) may seem arbitrary but serves to show God's comprehensive care
The theological concept that God's provision for animals shows His care for humans (who are made in His image) is a key point but might be hard to see without context

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does God's care for the animal kingdom (as shown in this chapter) apply to your life this week?
tips: Practice gratitude for God's provision of all creation, including animals
Recognize your limitations in understanding and controlling the world, and trust God's wisdom
This week, choose one animal that God cares for and pray for it, reflecting on God's care for all

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about God's care for the animal kingdom and your place in creation.
tips: Thank God for providing for the animals and showing His wisdom in creation
Ask God to help you recognize your limits and trust His provision in your life
Pray for humility and a deeper understanding of God's care for all creation

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 40:1-25 aloud, paying attention to God's challenge in verses 1-2 and the majestic description of Behemoth in verses 19-25.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'God' (v.1-2) to emphasize His sovereignty
Pay attention to the phrase 'Behemoth' (v.19) and the description of its power (v.20-21)
The tone shifts from challenging (v.1-8) to majestic (v.19-25)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God is speaking to, WHAT He challenges Job about, WHERE this happens (in the context of Job's suffering), and WHY God is doing this.
tips: Include God's challenge to Job's self-justification (v.1-2)
Note Job's silence (v.3-5)
Describe the description of Behemoth (v.19-25)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's challenge in verses 1-2, the description of Behemoth (verses 19-21), or the statement 'Only God can tame it' (verse 25)?
tips: God's challenge in v.1: 'Shall a faultfinder contend with the Almighty?' directly confronts Job's self-justification
The description of Behemoth (v.20-21) shows a creature that is both powerful and peaceful, which contrasts with human arrogance
The statement 'Only God can tame it' (v.25) emphasizes that God's authority is absolute and beyond human control

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was God trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage?
tips: God is showing that self-justification is impossible and that suffering is not a result of sin but of God's sovereignty
The description of Behemoth pictures forces beyond human control (like natural disasters, sin, death) that only God manages
This passage encourages trust in God's wisdom and power rather than human self-justification

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'Behemoth', why God describes it, and the phrase 'Only God can tame it'?
tips: The term 'Behemoth' is a Hebrew word for a large, powerful animal (likely the hippopotamus) but also could represent a primordial creature from God's creation
God describes Behemoth to show that even the most powerful creature is under His control and only He can tame it (v.25), which contrasts with Job's attempt to justify himself
The phrase 'tame' here means to control or subdue, not to domesticate in the modern sense

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: The passage shows that only God can handle forces beyond our control. What situation this week requires you to trust God's sovereignty instead of trying to control?
tips: Identify one area where you feel you are trying to control (e.g., anxiety, relationships, finances)
Pray for God to take that area and let Him handle it (like the Behemoth) rather than trying to tame it yourself
Write down one thing you can surrender to God this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His sovereignty and ask for the courage to trust Him in situations beyond your control.
tips: Thank God for His power to control all things (like the Behemoth)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 41:1-25 aloud, paying attention to the descriptions of Leviathan's power and the emotional tone of awe and terror.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'no one' (or 'none') in verses 3, 10, 12, 15, 17, 21, 24
Pay attention to the vivid imagery: 'sneeze flashes light', 'breath kindles coals', 'heart hard as stone'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (God) describes, WHAT (Leviathan), WHERE (the deep sea), and WHY (to show human powerlessness in the face of God's creation).
tips: Include the description of Leviathan's strength (vv. 1-25)
Note that God is the speaker and Leviathan is the creature described
Why this matters: It reassures the suffering that God is in control of all chaos

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Leviathan's sneeze flashing light (v.10), its heart hard as stone (v.15), or the closing statement 'God is Lord even of this' (v.25)?
tips: The image of Leviathan's sneeze flashing light shows the creature's immense power and connection to light (the divine)
The 'heart hard as stone' illustrates the creature's unyielding nature and the futility of human attempts to control it
The closing statement 'God is Lord even of this' ties the entire description to God's supreme authority

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Job trying to communicate to those who suffer through this passage?
tips: Job describes Leviathan to show that even the most powerful creature in creation is under God's control
This reassures the suffering that God is sovereign over all chaos and evil
Theologically, it points to the ultimate defeat of evil (Satan) through Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? Leviathan's identity, the phrase 'no one' in the Hebrew context, and the connection to Satan?
tips: Leviathan in ancient Near Eastern culture was a symbol of chaos and the sea, not a literal animal
The Hebrew word 'no one' (or 'none') in Job 41:3 emphasizes total powerlessness of humans against Leviathan
The passage connects to Christ: Leviathan represents Satan, who is defeated by the cross (Job 41:25)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the idea that God is Lord even of chaos to your current situation?
tips: In a time of anxiety or fear, remember that God is in control of all chaos (like the sea, the enemy, life's difficulties)
Pray for courage to trust God's sovereignty when faced with overwhelming challenges
Surrender a specific area of life (e.g., anxiety, relationship issues) to God, knowing He is Lord even of this

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being the Lord of all chaos and evil. Ask for courage to trust His sovereignty in your life.
tips: Thank God for being the Lord of Leviathan (the chaos) and for His provision
Pray for the strength to surrender to God when you feel overwhelmed by life's challenges
Ask God to help you see that even the most fearsome forces (like Satan) are under His authority

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Job 42:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between hearing and seeing in verses 5-6 and the humble repentance.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I had heard of you by the hearing of the ear, but now my eye sees you' (v.5) - it's a profound shift from hearing (theological knowledge) to seeing (personal relationship)
Pay attention to Job's humility: 'I despise myself and repent in dust and ashes' (v.6) - this shows total submission
The three friends are rebuked in v.7-8: 'The three friends of Job have spoken wrongly'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Job) repents, WHAT (his humble response to God), WHERE (in the context of his suffering), and WHY (after God's revelation in the previous chapters).
tips: Include Job's humble response in verses 5-6
Note that the three friends are rebuked and must offer sacrifices (verses 7-8)
Describe the restoration of Job's blessings (verses 10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Identify the most impactful verses that show Job's relationship with God and the restoration.
tips: The phrase 'I had heard of you by the hearing of the ear, but now my eye sees you' (v.5) reveals Job's shift from intellectual knowledge to personal relationship with God
Job's humility: 'I despise myself and repent in dust and ashes' (v.6) shows complete submission to God
The restoration: 'He had a double portion of livestock, ten more children, and 140 more years of life' (v.10) demonstrates God's abundant provision

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was God trying to communicate to those who suffer through Job's story?
tips: God reveals that true restoration comes through humble repentance and a personal relationship with Him, not through explanations or answers to problems
The restoration of Job's life (double the livestock, ten children, 140 years) shows God's abundant grace for those who humble themselves
This points to the Christian truth that Christ is the ultimate restorer and the one who sees us personally (John 14:9)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of Job's story are challenging to understand?
tips: The phrase 'I had heard of you by the hearing of the ear' (v.5) is metaphorical for knowing God through others' teachings, but Job now sees Him personally
The 'three friends' were wrong in their advice, but God gives them a chance to change (verses 7-8)
The restoration of 140 more years is not typical life expectancy (which was about 70-80) but shows God's abundant grace

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice humble repentance and trust in God's provision like Job?
tips: When you feel you don't understand God's plans, ask Him to reveal Him (like Job did) and then repent in humility
Share your struggles with others who might be in similar situations, just as Job prayed for his friends
Set a time this week to 'repent in dust and ashes' (v.6) by acknowledging your limitations and God's sufficiency

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about Job's repentance and restoration: Thank God for seeing you and restoring you when you humble yourself.
tips: Thank God for the relationship with Him that comes through humility (like Job)
Ask for the courage to repent when you don't understand
Pray for others who are suffering to have the same experience of God's restoration
